body_html:
@asimshankar Yes, I do. That's been fixed a long time ago in JavaCPP! :)

The problem is that on Windows it's not possible to delete a DLL after it's been loaded. We need to end the process, and let some other process do the clean up. I used to have a hack for that in JavaCPP but switched to using a cache instead, because it wouldn't work with JavaFX, among other things: bytedeco/javacpp#60

@sabi0 So, one way to work around this is by using the JavaCPP Presets for TensorFlow:
https://github.com/bytedeco/javacpp-presets/tree/master/tensorflow
You'll get access to the C++ API from Java, but we can keep using the official Java API as well.

A build for Windows has also been released:
bytedeco/javacpp-presets#111 (comment)

/cc @agibsonccc

@sabi0 So, one way to work around this is by using the JavaCPP Presets for TensorFlow:

You'll get access to the C++ API from Java, but we can keep using the official Java API as well.
A build for Windows has also been released:
bytedeco/javacpp-presets#111 (comment)

body:
@asimshankar Yes, I do. That's been fixed a long time ago in JavaCPP! :)

The problem is that on Windows it's not possible to delete a DLL after it's been loaded. We need to end the process, and let some other process do the clean up. I used to have a hack for that in JavaCPP but switched to using a cache instead, because it wouldn't work with JavaFX, among other things: https://github.com/bytedeco/javacpp/issues/60

@sabi0 So, one way to work around this is by using the JavaCPP Presets for TensorFlow:
https://github.com/bytedeco/javacpp-presets/tree/master/tensorflow
You'll get access to the C++ API from Java, but we can keep using the official Java API as well.

A build for Windows has also been released:
https://github.com/bytedeco/javacpp-presets/issues/111#issuecomment-380322141

/cc @agibsonccc
